qas.question: What makes up the law of criminal procedure?

answers.text: federal constitutional case law interwoven with the federal and state statutes

qas.question: What did the exclusionary rule provide for?

answers.text: inability of legislatures in the U.S. to enact statutes that would actually force law enforcement officers to respect the constitutional rights

qas.question: What might a suspect use to challenge their detention?
What must a police officer recite to a suspect upon arrest/
What acts cover tort damages from police brutality cases?

answers.text: Civil Rights Act of 1871 and Bivens actions

plausible_answers.text: statutes that would actually force law enforcement officers to respect the constitutional rights

qas.question: What have US legislatures been able to enact successfully?
What rule did the federal judiciary overturn?
When was the Miranda warning penned?
What do convicts use the Miranda warning for?

context: The law of criminal procedure in the United States consists of a massive overlay of <a0_0>federal constitutional case law interwoven with the federal and state statutes<a0_0/> that actually provide the foundation for the creation and operation of law enforcement agencies and prison systems as well as the proceedings in criminal trials. Due to the perennial <a1_0>inability of legislatures in the U.S. to enact <b5_0>statutes that would actually force law enforcement officers to respect the constitutional rights<b5_0/><a1_0/> of criminal suspects and convicts, the federal judiciary gradually developed <b6_0>the exclusionary rule<b6_0/> as a method to enforce such rights. In turn, the exclusionary rule spawned a family of judge-made remedies for the abuse of law enforcement powers, of which the most famous is the <a3_0>Miranda warning<a3_0/>. The <a2_0>writ of habeas corpus<a2_0/> is often used by suspects and convicts <b8_0>to challenge their detention<b8_0/>, while <b9_0>the <a4_0>Civil Rights Act<b9_0/> of <b7_0>1871<b7_0/> and Bivens actions<a4_0/> are used by suspects to recover tort damages for police brutality.
